definition:
A bound is *tight* if it can be realized. A bound that is not tight is
sometimes said to be *slack*.

For example, let $\mathcal{S}$ be the collection of all finite subsets
of $\mathbb{R}^2$ in general position. Define a function
$g\colon\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N}$ as follows. First, let the weight of an
element $S$ of $\mathcal{S}$ be the size of its largest convex subset,
that is,
$$w(S) = \max \{ |T| \colon T\subset S\text{\ and $T$ is convex} \}.$$
The function $g$ is defined by
$$g(n) = \min \{ |S| \colon w(S) \ge n\},$$ that is, $g(n)$ is the
smallest number such that any collection of $g(n)$ points in general
position contains a convex $n$-gon. (By the , $g(n)$ is always finite,
so $g$ is a well-defined function.) The bounds for $g$ due to Erdős and
Szekeres are $$2^{n-2} + 1\le g(n) \le \binom{2n-4}{n-2} + 1.$$ The
lower bound is tight because for each $n$, there is a set of $2^{n-2}$
points in general position which contains no convex $n$-gon. On the
other hand, the upper bound is believed to be slack. In fact, according
to the Erdős-Szekeres conjecture, the formula for $g(n)$ is exactly the
lower bound: $g(n) = 2^{n-2} + 1$.
